Radically more efficient use of energy than today, including electricity, is a complementary set of
In warmer climate regions undergoing economic transitions, improving the energy efficiency of cooling
and refrigeration equipment is often important for managing peak electricity demand and can have
benefits for climate mitigation as well as
reduction, as expected in India, Africa, and Southeast
Air conditioner adoption is rising significantly in
and average temperatures increase, including in Southeast Asian countries such as Thailand, Indonesia,
Vietnam, and the Philippines, as well as Brazil, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Nigeria
. Cooling appliances are expected to increase from 3.6 billion to 9.5 billion by 2050, though up to
4 billion could be required to provide adequate cooling for all
Current technology pathways are not sufficient to deliver universal access to cooling or meet the 2030
targets under the SDGs, but energy
efficiency, including in equipment efficiency like air conditioners,
can reduce this demand and help limit additional emissions that would further exacerbate climate
Africa) have started to recognise the need for more efficient equipment in their mitigation strategies
(Paladugula et al. 2018; Altieri et al. 2016; Ouedraogo 2017)
One possible synergy between SLCF and climate change mitigation is the simultaneous improvement
in energy efficiency in refrigeration and air
down, as recognised in the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol. The Kigali
Amendment and related national and regional regulations are projected to reduce future radiative
forcing from HFCs by about half in
2050 compared to a scenario without any HFC controls, and to
reduce future global average warming in 2100 from a baseline of 0.3
to a recent scientific assessment of a wide literature
ratified by signatories, the rapid phase
down of HFCs under the Kigali Amendment is possible because
global warming potential (GWP) HFCs with commercially available
GWP alternatives in refrigeration and air
conditioning equipment. Each countryâ€™s choices of
alternative refrigerants will likely be determined by energy efficiency, costs, and
and flammability. National and regional regulations will be needed to drive technological innovation

often focus more on building sector GHG emissions
mitigation measures such as improving building envelopes a
nd home appliances, and electrifying space
